turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Central Utah Project.
turn.1: What was the Central Utah Project?
turn.2: Central Utah Project The Central Utah Project is a US federal water project that was authorized for construction under the Colorado River Storage Project Act of April 11, 1956, as a participating project.
turn.4: In general, the Central Utah Project develops a portion of Utah's share of the yield of the Colorado River, as set out in the Colorado River Compact of 1922.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: As originally planned and authorized, the Central Utah Project consisted of six units or sub-projects: the Bonneville Unit, the Jensen Unit, the Vernal Unit, the Uinta Unit, the Upalco Unit, and Ute Indian Unit.
turn.7: What was the most important part?
turn.8: The largest and most complex is the Bonneville Unit, which diverts water from the Uinta Basin, a part of the Colorado River Basin, to the Lake Bonneville Basin.
turn.10: The other units were designed to provide for development of local water supplies in the Uinta Basin.
turn.12: The Central Utah Project develops water for irrigation, municipal, and industrial use; stream flows; and power generation.
